body: cc @danchia @yurishkuro
merging to test (by looking at jfrog)

reverted by https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/commit/4f75efe852319c49bc34ecbba2b6ec38bb0a109b

Basically, this is an unnecessary thing required by maven central policy. Easiest thing is just to ignore the extra assets. http://central.sonatype.org/pages/requirements.html#supply-javadoc-and-sources
cc @abesto @eirslett

Awesome, thank you!

Can do. Would also simplify the handler logic a bit. Reasoning for the current setup is in https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/1024#issuecomment-195077081

I have minimal experience with WebJars, was pretty smooth when I used it. But if we go that way, wouldn't we want to use that for dependency management (instead of `npm`)? How would that work together with webpack?

I think the two current consumers of this are already using maven
dependencies, and that simplifies the build quite a bit. I'd vote for a jar
with "/static" in it, as a published artifact (at least for now).

I've really no experience with webjars or webpack
SGTM. @eirslett, you mentioned this is easy to do with webpack?

There seems to be a missed dependency on `eslint-plugin-react`.

Here's what I'd do:

``` gradle
task npmLint(type: NpmTask) {
    args = ['run-script', 'lint']
    dependsOn npmInstall
}
check.dependsOn npmLint
```

Edit: this was implicit, but lemme state it explicitly: yes, I think making code quality checks part of the build process is great. I'm all for it.

This assumes the "vision" is to stay with NPM for the duration. If instead we want to replace NPM and keep webpack + karma, the same argument says we need to NOT include `npm` in the name of the tasks, and this should not be merged.

Maybe we could check whether the first character in a message is [ and if that's the case, interpret it as a json list of spans.

I'm cool with the peek option. We already have to peek anyway. When we move
to a different model, we'd probably want to use a message key instead, and
it might look like a media type.

ex. application/vnd.zipkin2.tracelist+json
To kill an ostrich.. This is what you seek?
Whoot!

I was going to suggest this! Thanks for implementing before I had the
chance to.

Do we want to call this config.json or just config? I can see the case for the former, as it looks like a file and could be implemented by one. The latter looks more like other things like /healthcheck (assuming content-type is correct)

Thoughts?

cc @eirslett @abesto 

I tested this locally with both explicit paths and bundled ones.. the flag is compatible with before, but better worded and with a better error message.
Great, thanks a lot!! +1
The idea was that, like you said, people could host the ui from a web server like apache httpd, and simply configure it by creating their own config.json.
WFM
@adriancole @eirslett The Scala is slowly coming back to me, please check to see if I made a mess or not.

Side-note: I kind of feel like changing `index.html` to refer to `/static/*.js` instead of `/*.js`. That would make the handlers considerably simpler, and just feels nice. How would that play together with Spring etc.?
LGTM: only comment would be to add a comment from your PR near the code

I don't think it would play nice :) basically they would be nested in the
jar under static/static. In spring and other containers, "static/" or
"public/" basically acts as a content chroot.
We could serve them under "dist", so the folder structure would be /static/index.html, /static/dist/app.min.js and so on.

my jdk is 1.8, and my os is OSX, i use the step like this:

$git clone https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin /var/www/zipkin
$cd /var/www/zipkin
$./bin/query

I think you are trying to pass gradle args to the shell scripts. They
aren't written to do that.

The only arg to pass to collector or query is the storage type. ex
cassandra or mysql (or leave it out to be local).

Ex. bin/query cassandra

you can what's going on by doing "bash -x bin/query cassandra"

underneath, you'll notice it calls gradle internally. You can feel free to
do that as well.

Hope this helps!
@adriancole thanks a lot,now it looks good when  i remove the arg..
SGTM. Would we want to set up the same folder structure inside the jar? I imagine that'd make routing easier on users (see https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/98#issuecomment-197276575)

That's correct. zipkin-query-service and collector still use the old scala
config approach.
This is why things are done with env vars, btw
Also. @adriancole @eirslett I propose we merge this to un-break master and re-think the folder structure if need be, in another PR. Go?
Tried to reproduce on `zipkin-web-serve-from-static-dir`, now I get the same breakage there. I'm confused about how it worked previously.

There’s some special logic in `zipkin-web` to not trace static assets, may be worth porting here. See https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-web/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/web/FilteredHttpEntrypointTraceInitializer.scala and https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-web/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/web/Main.scala#L116-L121. (Not sure it applies, or applies directly)
@abesto yeah that could be joined with FilteredHttpEntrypointTraceInitializer in zipkin-query
works as advertised!

Closing due to lack of activity. Zipkin is no longer based on Finagle directly, but on Finatra.
I think you're left with 2 options:

1) put nginx/apache/something in front of zipkin, to handle authentication (cannot be fine-grained)
2) fork zipkin, to make a version with authentication support

We're quite limited on resources, so I don't think autentication is something we would prioritise. (Feel free to reopenthis issue if any project members disagree!)
